title: A legacy of conquests
text:
Malacca (spelled Melaka in Malaysia) is a state off the shores of the Melacca Strait. The city, Malacca City, has been a UNESCO World Heritage Site since 2008. Occupied by the Portugese in 1511, the Dutch in 1641, and then the British in 1824, it is a diverse melting pot of cultures. I was never going to pass up on the opportunity to visit Malacca.






Figure 1: Christ Church Melaka at the Dutch Red Square. A historic, red-painted Protestant church with a bell tower.

title: A legacy of conquests
text:
Getting there
Being an overland backpacker, flying was out of the question. There is no rail line connecting Kuala Lumpur to Malacca — at least not one that I am aware of — which means coach it is.

1. Kuala Lumpur City to Terminal Bersepadu Selatan
My first task was to make my way to the Terminal Bersepadu Selatan (TBS) bus station. This is a ginormous bus station that has coaches leaving to all corners of the East Malaysian peninsula, including to Singapore (and possibly to Thailand).
With time on my hands and luxury the least of my concerns, I hopped on the light rail at Plaza Rakyat nearest my hotel and rode seven stops to Bandar Tasik Selatan for 3 MYR — the ticket was actually 2.90 MYR, but the ticket machines do not accept cards and do not dispense change; so, I was robbed of 0.10 MYR (~£0.02)!
Bandar Tasik Selatan is connected to the TBS by a bridge. There was no need to leave the station.


2. TBS to Melaka Sentral
At the counter, I bought the 11:45 to Melaka Sentral, operated by Melor Interline, for 12 MYR. Delayed by 15 minutes, the coach was mostly empty and spacious and the journey itself was a straight forward two hours.











(a) Ticket to Malacca.











(b) Coach from TBS to Malacca mostly empty.







Figure 2: Terminal Bersepadu Selatan.





3. Melaka Sentral to Melaka City
Arriving at Melaka Sentral gives you the first indication that all is not well in Malacca: a moderately-sized bus station haunted by bleak and derelict shop units that hark back to past fortunes. The information desk looked like it was abandoned long ago, but after some walking around and asking it turned out that intercity coaches terminated at one end of the station, while local buses terminated at the opposite end.
A taxi to the city centre was just shy of 10 MYR, but I wanted to travel like a local. At the local end of the station, the bus at bay 16 took me through the city centre at a cost 1.40 MYR and about 45 minutes (actually, it cost me 5 MYR, because the bus does not give change. Robbed again of 3.60 MYR, ~£0.72!).











(a) Local bus bay 16 took me to Mahkota Parade in the city centre.











(b) Ticket from Melaka Sentral to Mahkota Parade.







Figure 3: Melaka Sentral.

title: A legacy of conquests
text:
My thoughts
The historical areas of Malacca are brimming with life, supported by an army of tourists. The Red Square (Figure 1) — a historic square from the Dutch colonial era, featuring red-brick buildings — is quite nice, tacky trinkets notwithstanding.
The Melacca Mosque is quite simply breathtaking.











(a) Approaching the Masjid Selat Melaka.











(b) Masjid Selat Melaka on the Malacca Strait.













(c) Inside the Masjid Selat Melaka.











(d) Inside the Masjid Selat Melaka.







Figure 5: Masjid Selat Melaka.



If you venture out of the tourist hotspots, you will find that Malacca city never recovered from covid. Certain areas are completely mothballed, with ambitious development projects stopped and livelihoods destroyed. Walking into some of these desolate places is like a dystopian nightmare.






Figure 6: An abandoned housing estate.

title: Where the two rivers meet
text:
Kuala Lumpur is the first stop in my Asia trip. Founded on the muddy confluence of the Gumbak and Klang rivers by, in part, Chinese tin miners and bat poo excavators in the 1800s, it is today one of the fastest growing cities in South East Asia.






Figure 1: Where the two rivers meet. Jame Masjid at the confluence of the Gumbak (left) and Klang (right) rivers. It is quite pretty at night.



I had heard great things about Kuala Lumpur and it sounded like the perfect place to kickstart my Asia tour. People appear to treat it as base to come back to as they travel around neighbouring countries.

title: Where the two rivers meet
text:
Getting there
I hate flying, mostly because I hate airports and all the wasted time in waiting around, standing in lines, going through security after security, followed by some more waiting around in departure lounges. It also happens to be one of the few things that bring out the worst in humanity — in my experience, at least. In any case, it was the only reasonable way of my getting there — walking, driving, or sailing really was not an option.
I bought a one-way ticket to Kuala Lumpur from Manchester, to transit at Abu Dhabi, for £445.63. Many countries will refuse you entry if you cannot show onward travel documents. There is no mention of this for Malaysia on the FCDO, but, just to be safe, I paid 5 MYR (~£1) for a train ticket from the last stop in Malaysia (JB Sentral) to the first stop in Singapore (Woodlands). There is a company that specialises in sorting out onward air tickets, aptly called Onward Ticket, but parting with £20 just seemed a waste of money to me.

1: Manchester Airport to Abu Dhabi Airport
This was a six-hour 30-minute flight, made bearable only by the two people sat next to me: Dianne and Liam, a couple in their mid-50s from Yorkshire flying to Goa, India. Dianne, an easy conversationalist, is an avid motorbiker. She regaled me with stories of how she and Liam rode east to west on a Harley in the US, and similar trips to continental Europe. Being a biker myself, I was, of course, jealous but happy for them. They were nice and more than happy to share their stories (and snacks!).


2: Abu Dhabi Airport to Kuala Lumpur Airport
I was meant to transit in Abu Dhabi for one hour 30 minutes, but with delays taking off from Manchester it was essentially a hop-off-hop-on at Abu Dhabi.
Elated at being seated near to the door where there is ample leg space without my having to fork out any extra money, my elation quickly turned into despair after I was quickly surrounded by three incessantly crying babies and their useless parents in tow.






Tip



Never pay extra for the seats at the front; they are usually reserved for parents with babies.


Needless to say, not an ounce of sleep or peace came my way and, after an excruciating seven-hour ordeal, I was more than happy to bolt out the exit as soon as the plane landed. I had no desire to relive the ordeal at the immigration line. Did I tell you I hated flying?
It turns out, Malaysia no longer have traditional immigration counters where passports are stamped. You self-declare a mandatory MDAC before you arrive and scan your passport at the gate and that is it. You are free to go. Of course, for some countries, the full KY jelly and rubber glove treatment still applies.
Though it is far less hassle and bureaucratic, I miss not having my passport stamped. I mean, having a passport full of stamps from different countries is part of a backpacker’s experience — like an official record of when and where you said no to the sedentary life in favour of the nomadic wilderness. But, I guess, life is transient and these worldly inks are just as ephemeral.


3: Kuala Lumpur Airport to Kuala Lumpur City Centre
Like all airports, Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA) is quite a way away from Kuala Lumpur city centre; so, the first thing I needed to do was make my way to the centre. My options were

Taxi
Use the Grab app (South East Asia’s most popular taxi app). Cost: no more than 110 MYR (~20 GBP).
Train
There are two trains: (i) KL Transit and (ii) KL Ekspress (yes, that is how they spell it). They are essentially the same, except the KL Ekspress is a direct, non-stop, airport-centre service. Cost: 55 MYR (~10 GBP), taking 30 minutes.
Bus
Cost: 15 MYR (~3 GBP), taking upwards of an hour.

Being a backpacker, I was never going to take the taxi option. I had wanted to take the bus, but, after 14 hours on an aeroplane, cramped like sardines in a can (at first) and devoid of any sleep (second), I decided to take the KL Ekspress direct to KL Sentral.
Arriving at KL Sentral, the immediate area surrounding the train station is not pedestrian friendly. With a spaghetti mess of mutiple-lane carriageways snaking around multiple train stations close by, it was a mare trying to navigate my way out north. It was hot (28 °C), it was humid, and the air felt stale, but the life of a backpacker is to see the world and so I was never going to call a taxi. I ploughed on ahead on foot.
Though I was tired, it was still too early to check into my hotel. I needed to slow down. I visited the National Mosque of Malaysia, Independence Square, the National Textiles Museum, and the beautiful Sultan Abdul Samad Building.











(a) The mosque from the outside.











(b) Main prayer hall.







Figure 2: The National Mosque of Malaysia.









Figure 3: The National Textile Museum building in the distance.



On top of being sleep-deprived, I was now hungry and sweating profusely. Blundering my way ever-forward, I stumbled upon a strong and vibrant south Indian and Bangladeshi community in the Masjid India (aka Little India) corner of Kuala Lumpur. I walked into a restaurant hoping for a strong desi chai to keep me awake. The boy who served me — a young boy in his late teens from Tamil Nadu — suggested I try their traditional food, served in their traditional manner: on the leaf of a banana tree.






Figure 4: Food on the leaf of a banana tree. All for a princely sum of 8 MYR (~1.50 GBP).



The food was nice and it hit the spot, but more than anything it was served with love. The boy sat with me and talked about how today was the Pongol festival back home and how he dearly missed not being there with his family. He came to Malaysia to earn money, given the lack of opportunities in his home country.
Stepping out of the restaurant’s cool beguiling air and into the outside heat, it struck me again just how hot Malaysia is. Of course, I knew this beforehand. It’s January, I thought; it should be a little cooler, right?

title: Where the two rivers meet
text:
Climate
Why so hot?
There are many facets to climate, but the ones I care about most right now are temperature and humidity.
There is an R package called {riem} that allows you to get hold of weather data from Automated Surface Observing Systems (ASOS). These are weather stations found in airports all aound the world, many of which have been collecting data for more than 50 years. The KLIA dataset stretches back to 1949, but limiting myself to 2010 it looks like Kuala Lumpur’s temperature hovers aound 28 °C \(\pm\) 2 °C, while relative humidity hovers around 80% all year round. It is not uncommon for several days in a month to reach 100% relative humidity.











(a) Temperature in Kuala Lumpur.













(b) Relative humidity in Kuala Lumpur.







Figure 5: Climate in Kuala Lumpur.1



Insofar as temperature and relative humidity are concerned, Kuala Lumpur is quite monoclimatic year-round. At 80% relative humidity, no wonder you feel so hot: with the air already saturated with water, it is difficult for your sweat to evaporate and transfer the thermal energy into the surroundings.

I want to explore the various quarters around Kuala Lumpur and what the city has to offer. My next port of call will probably be Malacca and then further south towards Singapore, given that I now have a ticket!
Keep a look out for my next post.

title: Squaring the circle
text: Back in 1999, the Malaysian government decided to move from the centre of Kuala Lumpur to Putrajaya, about 16 miles due south. Having made my way to Kuala Lumpur, it would have been a shame to not make a quick, cheeky, visit to the new centre of government.

title: Squaring the circle
text: Back in 1999, the Malaysian government decided to move from the centre of Kuala Lumpur to Putrajaya, about 16 miles due south. Having made my way to Kuala Lumpur, it would have been a shame to not make a quick, cheeky, visit to the new centre of government.

title: Squaring the circle
text:
Getting there
The bus KRTravelT523 leaves hourly from Hab Lebuh Pudu bus station and takes about an hour to get straight to the action in Putra Square. It costs 4 MYR (~£0.80 GBP), which is great value for an hour’s bus ride.











(a) The KRTravelT523 bus at Hab Lebuh Pudu bust station.











(b) Inside the KRTravelT523 bus.







Figure 1: Hab Lebuh Pudu bus station.



The driver allowed passengers to board at 09:45 and departed exactly on schedule, 10:00. So, make sure you are on time.






Figure 2: One-hour bus journey to Putra Square.

title: Squaring the circle
text:
Putra Square
As with all city “squares” out there, I have no idea why they call it a square, because it is actually a circle. In any case, as the bus arrives at Putra Square, you can see that the government mean business: grand structures designed with an infusion of cultures ready to stand the test of time, with a hint of intent, signalling to the world that Malaysia’s time has come.

Prime Minister’s office
For obvious reasons, the Prime Minister’s office is not accessible to the general public.











(a) Putra Square. Prime Minister’s office in the distance.











(b) Prime Minister’s office, viewed from Putra Masjid.







Figure 3: Putra Square and the Prime Mininster’s office.





Putra Masjid
The Putra Masjid sits adjacent to the Prime Minister’s office. It was constructed in 1999 with rose-tinted granite on the banks of the Putrajaya Lake, a 650-hectare man-made colossal cooling system.











(a) Putra Masjid.











(b) Putra Masjid, viewed from Putra Square.













(c) Flower gardens on the perimeter of Putra Masjid.











(d) The Qur’an in Putra Masjid.







Figure 4: The Putra Masjid in Putra Square.

title: Squaring the circle
text:
Other activities
Once you have had a wander around the square, the mosque, the artisan stalls, shopping mall, you can take a boat ride on the lake, from where the mosque appears to float on water.
